title: Uncovering Prison Deaths
text:
Uncovering Prison Deaths


Facility-level insights into where, when, and why people are dying in custody.

View Key Findings

title: About
text:
Each year, people die in the custody of West Virginia’s Division of Corrections and Rehabilitation (DCR)—but the public rarely learns who they were, where they died, or what happened to them.
This site exists to change that.
It presents the first facility-level dataset of reported deaths in DCR custody, covering both prisons and regional jails. The data comes from Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests and includes details that are not available in DCR’s public reports:

Date of death

Facility name

Age, race, and gender

Manner and cause of death

Whether the person was awaiting trial or already sentenced

title: About
text:
Background
The UCLA Law Behind Bars Data Project began in March 2020 to track the impact of COVID-19 on incarcerated people and corrections staff. As the pandemic exposed deep vulnerabilities in carceral systems, the project became a vital resource for:

Advocates and legal teams fighting for urgent reforms

Journalists and researchers investigating conditions behind bars

Policymakers aiming to understand the scope of the crisis

In February 2023, the project expanded beyond COVID and relaunched with a focus on all-cause mortality in U.S. prisons and jails. The result is the most comprehensive public dataset of deaths in custody nationwide—filling a critical gap left by the federal government’s cessation of mortality reporting in 2019.
This dataset has already shaped national discourse. A front-page New York Times investigation, using Behind Bars data, found a 61% increase in prison mortality from 2019 to 2020. West Virginia stood out with the highest known mortality rate—96 deaths per 10,000 people incarcerated.

title: About
text:
My Contribution
This site presents an independent analysis using data from the UCLA Law Behind Bars Data Project, combined with additional public records and state-level information. Specifically:

I downloaded the deaths in custody dataset from the project’s GitHub repository

I focused on West Virginia, a state where I’ve led cross-system justice data work

I incorporated contextual insights on carceral conditions, health care access, and system capacity in WV

My goal is to highlight how this dataset can support deeper, local investigations into carceral mortality—especially in states like West Virginia, where deaths in custody are consistently high but poorly understood.

title: About
text:
Objectives

Use UCLA’s mortality dataset to explore state- and facility-level patterns

Highlight mortality trends in West Virginia, using my prior work in that system as context

Identify policy-relevant factors that may drive or mitigate deaths behind bars

Demonstrate how public data can be used to inform oversight and accountability


Key Questions

Which facilities report the highest rates of mortality?
What patterns can be observed across time, states, or populations?
How does West Virginia compare to other states, and why?
What structural factors—staffing, aging populations, medical care—may explain elevated death rates?

title: About
section: What’s really happening inside West Virginia’s jails and prisons?
text:
What’s really happening inside West Virginia’s jails and prisons?
Each year, people die in the custody of West Virginia’s Division of Corrections and Rehabilitation (DCR)—but the public rarely learns who they were, where they died, or what happened to them.
This site exists to change that.
It presents the first facility-level dataset of reported deaths in DCR custody, covering both prisons and regional jails. The data comes from Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests and includes details that are not available in DCR’s public reports:

Date of death

Facility name

Age, race, and gender

Manner and cause of death

Whether the person was awaiting trial or already sentenced

title: About
section: What DCR publishes—and what it leaves out
text:
What DCR publishes—and what it leaves out
DCR’s official reports include:

Only prison deaths

Only aggregate counts, broken down by month and year

They do not include:

Deaths in regional jails

Any information about age, race, gender, cause of death, or facility

Any case-level details or names of the deceased

title: About
text:
What this dataset includes
In 2024, Sara Whitaker, a policy analyst with the West Virginia Center on Budget and Policy, submitted a FOIA request to DCR for:

All deaths in DCR custody since 2020

Facility-level, demographic, and cause-of-death information

Records of deaths following hospital transfers or administrative releases

The result was a case-level dataset of over 180 deaths between January 2020 and March 2025, covering both jails and prisons.

Sara Whitaker’s findings revealed:

Deaths in jails that had never been disclosed publicly

Mismatches between FOIA results and official totals

Minimal classification of cause, with many deaths listed only as “natural” or “overdose”

Exclusion of cases if death occurred in a hospital, even when the individual remained in DCR custody


Example: Marissa Crim died less than 24 hours after being booked into North Central Regional Jail. Her death was not included in DCR’s monthly log, despite the jail informing the prosecutor that she died in custody.

title: About
text:
Why this matters
West Virginia has had one of the highest jail death rates in the country over the past decade. But with no facility-level reporting, there is:

No transparency around which jails or prisons are most at risk

No public system to track systemic failures like overcrowding or neglect

No routine disclosure when people die in government custody

Without outside scrutiny, the system operates in silence—even as lawsuits and investigative reporting reveal troubling patterns.

title: About
text:
This project aims to:

Document all known deaths in DCR custody since 2020

Provide facility-level data to support public awareness and oversight

Compare FOIA data with:

WV DCR annual reports (which exclude jail deaths)

UCLA Behind Bars Data Project (national data built from media and public records)

title: About
section: What DCR reports—and what it doesn’t
text:
What DCR reports—and what it doesn’t
In its annual reports, DCR lists only the number of deaths in state prisons, broken down by month and year. But:

Deaths in jails are excluded entirely
There is no breakdown by facility, demographics, or cause
No names, narratives, or circumstances are ever shared

This means the public cannot see patterns, identify red flags, or hold the system accountable.

title: About
text:
What this dataset adds
In 2024, policy analyst Sara Whitaker of the WV Center on Budget and Policy submitted a FOIA request asking DCR to release:

All deaths in custody since 2020

Records covering prisons, jails, hospital transfers, and administrative releases

Case-level details on each person who died

The dataset includes 289 deaths in DCR custody from January 2020 to March 2025, based on six tables released via FOIA to policy analyst Sarah Whitaker.
Sara Whitaker found that:

Many jail deaths were not disclosed in prior DCR reports

Some deaths were excluded from official tallies if they happened after a hospital transfer or administrative release

DCR often labeled deaths as “natural” or “overdose” without providing details, even in cases involving violence or neglect

Families were not notified publicly, and several deaths only came to light through litigation

title: About
section: What this project aims to do
text:
What this project aims to do
This project uses the FOIA-released dataset to:

Document deaths in West Virginia’s jails and prisons from 2020–2025

Provide facility-level transparency where none previously existed

Support journalists, watchdogs, and advocates working toward oversight

Compare FOIA records with WV DCR annual reports and the UCLA Behind Bars national database to surface discrepancies

Raise new questions about facility conditions, medical care, and system design
